t: Proverbs 25
More Proverbs of Solomon
These*p also are proverbs of Solomon which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied.
It*pn is the glory of God to conceal things, but*ld the glory of kings is to search things out.
As*ln the heavens for height, and the earth for depth, so*ld the heart of kings is unsearchable.
Take*ln away the dross from the silver, and*ld the smith has material for a vessel;
take*ln away the wicked from the presence of the king, and*ld his throne will be established in righteousness.
Do*ln not put yourself forward in the king’s presence or*ld stand in the place of the great,
for*ln it is better to be told, “Come up here,” than*ld to be put lower in the presence of a noble. What*pn your eyes have seen
do*ld not hastily bring into court, for*ln what will you do in the end, when*ld your neighbor puts you to shame?
Argue*ln your case with your neighbor himself, and*ld do not reveal another’s secret,
lest*ln he who hears you bring shame upon you, and*ld your ill repute have no end.
A*pn word fitly spoken is*ld like apples of gold in a setting of silver.
Like*ln a gold ring or an ornament of gold is*ld a wise reprover to a listening ear.
Like*ln the cold of snow in the time of harvest is*ld a faithful messenger to those who send him; he*ld refreshes the soul of his masters.
Like*ln clouds and wind without rain is*ld a man who boasts of a gift he does not give.
With*pn patience a ruler may be persuaded, and*ld a soft tongue will break a bone.
If*ln you have found honey, eat only enough for you, lest*ld you have your fill of it and vomit it.
Let*ln your foot be seldom in your neighbor’s house, lest*ld he have his fill of you and hate you.
A*ln man who bears false witness against his neighbor is*ld like a war club, or a sword, or a sharp arrow.
Trusting*ln in a treacherous man in time of trouble is*ld like a bad tooth or a foot that slips.
Whoever*ln sings songs to a heavy heart is*ld like one who takes off a garment on a cold day, and*ld like vinegar on soda.
If*ln your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat, and*ld if he is thirsty, give him water to drink,
for*ln you will heap burning coals on his head, and*ld the Lord*s will reward you.
The*ln north wind brings forth rain, and*ld a backbiting tongue, angry looks.
It*ln is better to live in a corner of the housetop than*ld in a house shared with a quarrelsome wife.
Like*ln cold water to a thirsty soul, so*ld is good news from a far country.
Like*ln a muddied spring or a polluted fountain is*ld a righteous man who gives way before the wicked.
It*ln is not good to eat much honey, nor*ld is it glorious to seek one’s own glory.
A*ln man without self-control is*ld like a city broken into and left without walls.
